course_title: Topics in Afr American Studies: African American Language
class_notes: (Same as LING 340 1, ANT 340 1)  Theoretical linguists are often concerned with how language is organized in the abstract. Psycholinguistics is a relatively young, but rapidly growing discipline that addresses how language might be realized as a component within the general cognitive system, and how language is comprehended, produced, and represented in memory. It is an interdisciplinary effort, drawing on research and techniques from linguistics, psychology, neuroscience, and computer science, and utilizes a variety of methods to investigate the underlying representations and mechanisms that are involved in linguistic computations. Moreover, psycholinguistics does more than simply describe the facts; it attempts to weave what is known about how humans produce and process language into a coherent cognitive system, with enough structure so that we can study its composition in a rigorous, hypothesis driven way. The core areas of psycholinguistics include language acquisition, language production, language comprehension, and language disorders and damage. The major themes of the course are as follows: Uncovering and characterizing the subsystems that account for linguistic performance; How such subsystems interact, and whether they interact within a fixed order; How the major linguistic subsystems relate to more general cognitive mechanisms.
course_description: This course explores one of a wide range of topics pertaining to the African American experience in the fields of human and civil rights, social and literary texts, and the social sciences.
